comment.author: 69751036@N08
comment._content: The engineering in these is fantastic.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From wikipedia: The Great Northern Railway (Ireland) straddled the border between the Republic and Northern Ireland, and so was not incorporated in either the CIE or UTA. However, mounting losses saw the network purchased jointly by the Irish and British governments on 1 September 1953. It was run as a joint board, independent of the CIE and UTA, until 30 September 1958 when it was dissolved and the remaining stock split equally between the two railways. Class VS: Numbers 206-210

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Mentioned in this pdf as one of the first candidates for preservation by the RPI in the 70s, but they didn't have funds. It was used for an outing on the Belfast to Dublin line in April 1964. Steam was already finished in the Republic in 1964 when these photos were taken, but some steam locos were still used in the North for shunting and freight.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: How the times have changed?  Steam is but a memory and not for too many either, throwing the ash out like that would never by tolerated now, using a shovel would not be an option and a vacuum extractor would be in place and the worker would have to wear a heap of PPE and be in a harnes in case he fell off the engine.  Great study and very clear shot.

comment._content: That was one manky job to do!

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content:
We would call that a 4-4-4 based on the Whyte notation system in North America (based on the number of wheels under the locomotive; leading wheels, driving wheels, trailing wheels).Known as the Reading or Jubilee type in Canada.

 They use a different system in Europe. I'll leave it to the railfans over there to fill us in...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Definitely called a 4-4-0 here, in fact one of the last 4-4-0s made in the UK.. The four or six wheels on the tender don't count. I believe that's a 4000 (Imperial) gallon tender.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Yes I believe these were one of the last 4-4-0 locomotives to be built (1948) in Europe (or even the world?). As Nail mentions, known as the Great Northern 'VS Class' and numbered 206-210, they were the only class of Irish steam locos to be fitted with smoke deflectors, to prevent smoke from obscuring the driver's view. As a tribute to these engines, the present 201 Class Enterprise locos carry the same names as the VSs. The VS locos still operated the occasional Dublin-Belfast Enterprise service until at least 1965.
